awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   A Multimodal Mixed-Initiative Research Notebook for Information Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
While search engines address the problem of helping people find particular information, they are not directly built to support people developing creative ideas. This research supports people engaged in sustained information discovery tasks, such as invention and thesis development, in which the goal is to create new knowledge by forming ideas while finding and assembling information. New modalities of human computer interaction will be developed to support people engaged in assembling their building blocks of invention, utilizing information semantics, dynamic organization, and visualization. The approach is based on the form of composition, which visually and conceptually integrates elements to represent a collection. The research notebook will support sustained innovation, in which people need to connect and integrate key findings in the collections they create while conducting research and invention over time. Physically-based techniques, such as mass-spring and flocking models, will be applied and extended to facilitate human manipulation of collections as compositions. New modalities of interaction, such as pen-based, will improve sensory feedback and engagement by enabling participants to literally get their hands into digital information. The physically-based techniques and new interaction modalities will be integrated with the combinFormation mixed-initiative composition platform to provide a basis for augmenting the research notebook beyond the desktop metaphor.  Our principal hypothesis is that mixed-initiative composition and physically-based multimodal interaction will improve the emergence of new ideas during individual and team-based information discovery tasks. Using the research notebook on assignments by over 1,000 undergraduate students developing new inventions each year in The Design Process course will catalyze innovative education, while also generating evaluation data on information discovery.

The proposed research is innovative in its interdisciplinary approach, expected to yield significant outcomes: (1)  new techniques for physically-based interaction with information; (2) new multimodal techniques for interaction with information; (3) new integrated semantic, visual, and interactive methods for supporting human discovery of connections among ideas; (4) a research notebook infrastructure for supporting sustained interaction with digital information by students and researchers; (5) new data about how students and researchers develop ideas over time in practice; (6) new understanding of creative processes that make up research and invention; and (7) new methods for supporting research and invention in education. Advanced learning technologies developed by this proposal will be implemented and distributed through the Research Notebook and the combinFormation platform. Software technologies will be made available to the students and the public through the web. A multimodal interaction lab will make integrated software/hardware systems available to some of the students. The Research Notebook methods, techniques, and cyberinfrastructure can amplify the productivity of scientists. The new interactive techniques for discovery and semantics can transform how students, researchers, knowledge workers, and the public experience the internet and digital repositories. The integration into education of research issues, designs, and implementations, with a learner-centered approach, will contribute to the development of a new generation of creativity-oriented human-centered computing researchers and practitioners.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
CAREER: A Multimodal Mixed-Initiative Research Notebook for Information Discovery

The PI lead an investigation into how spatial organization, visual thinking, and embodied interaction in interfaces for representing collections of information resources can help people be creative. The notion of information discovery evolved to information-based ideation, explicitly moving the focus to people's processes of imagining and developing new ideas. The notion of information composition evolved to free-form web curation, which emphasizes the use of space and scale as a means for organizing collections, while situating the creative process of gathering and annotating directly in the web browser, which is where the user is often already working. Free-form curation also incorporates a zoomable user interface, which helps people organize more information clippings at one time, and sketching, a key modality of visual thinking.

The foundation of our approach is the "visual and semantic" clipping, that is, an image, from an article, which links back to the article and is enriched with a semantic summary. The initial focus of the award was to study mixed-initiative information composition, that is, the integration of direct manipulation interaction, in which the user gathers and visually organizes information, with a generative visual and semantic component for gathering and visually organizing such information, based on an evolving model of the user's needs.

We conducted a series of laboratory studies, which showed that mixed-initiative information composition does, in fact, support ideation. When people work on their own, first on a creative task, then receive stimulus from the generative visual and semantic component, we showed that they generate more diverse and emergent ideas. Also, we showed that the spatial and semantic integration of curation space with information gathering space, with semantic summaries consistently maintained across the boundary, helps people generate more diverse and novel ideas. In order to achieve these findings by deriving and applying novel ideation metrics for variety, novelty, and emergence.

We conducted a series of field studies, in which our information composition and free-form web curation systems are used in coursework. Altogether, the interactive systems developed with support from this CAREER award—combinFormation, InfoComposer, and IdeaMâché—have been used by 6389 students in 26 offerings of 13 courses, involving 9 instructors, over the period of the award. The fields of these courses include Environmental Design, Landscape Architecture, and Communication, as well as the PI's home Department of Computer Science and Engineering.

In the field studies, the PI's team observed that while the generative component was stimulating and valuable, the need for better capabilities for direct manipulation of visual and semantic clippings, along with sketching and writing, was paramount in the user experience. Thus, an outcome of this CAREER award is that the PI has shifted his attention to directly supporting free-form web curation. My Interface Ecology Lab team is pursuing this approach both on the desktop, with mouse and keyboard, and also with multimodal pen+touch interaction. Through a study with Landscape Architecture students, we found that fluid pen+touch interaction supports visual thinking and design ideation.

We developed a definition: Free-form web curation is a form of new media—designed to support users in creating new conceptual and spatial contexts—in which they discover, interpret, and represent relationships, by composing content elements into a connected whole. People engage in free-form web curation as a means of performing diverse ideation tasks involving multimedia "prior work" and live streams. Doing free-form web curation involves the invocation of creative strategies: Collect, Assemble, Shift Perspective, Sketch, Write, and Exhibit.

The PI has integrated free-form web curation into assignments in his undergraduate half-capstone course, Programming Studio, his advanced undergraduate course, Structures of Interactive Information, his graduate introductory methods course, Human-Centered Computing, and his advanced graduate course, Seminar in Human-Centered Computing and Information. In these courses, free-form web curation plays the evolved role foreseen in the foundation of this award -- that of research notebook. The research notebook function has evolved to be visual and free-form, supplanting the traditional format of a sequence of discrete textual entries. The result is that the new form helps students discover emergent relationships among sketches, notes, found information, prototypes, and other ideational elements, over the course of a research or design project.



 

 


Last Modified: 04/21/2017
Modified by: Andruid Kerne

Images (1 of )
  • In the free-form curation for ideation in the design of an innovative product, undergraduate Jordan Jump's Laundry Notifier spatially organizes diverse elements--a conceptual statement, potential devices and companies to partner with, and patents of prior products--over a washing machine.
    Interface Ecology Lab and Jordan Jump
    Copyrighted
    Andruid Kerne
    Laundry Notifier, an invention ideation free-form web curation.
  • In Scoliosis, a personal health informatics free-form curation, undergraduate Katharine Kimmel manifests visual thinking by assembling her own sketches and writing with images from the web and YouTube videos [https://ideamache.ecologylab.net/v/bM6IaLoVvT/].The curation is educational and hopeful.
    Interface Ecology Lab / Katharine Kimmel
    Copyrighted
    Andruid Kerne
    Scoliosis, a personal health informatics free-form web curation.
  • "Andrew M. Webb, Ph.D. student, curated Graphic Sign System: Analysis of Information as a visual aid for his presentation on Bertin's, Semiology of Graphics: Diagrams, Networks, Maps for the graduate seminar, Curation and Ideation meet Social Media [https://ideamache.ecologylab.net/v/Hz9Ky6Uh6x/].
    Interface Ecology Lab and Andrew M. Webb
    Copyrighted
    Andruid Kerne
    Graphic Sign System: Analysis of Information, a free-form web curation for teaching information design.
  • This free-form curation, buffer zone, arranges beachfront and satellite coastal images in grids [https://ideamache.ecologylab. net/v/6F7MNpHZ8K/]. Visual thinking contrasts approaches to flood management in the Netherlands and Texas. Sketches over images analyze and abstract visual forms.
    Interface Ecology Lab
    Copyrighted
    Andruid Kerne
    buffer zone, an exercise in critical landscape architecture design through free-form web curation.
  • This curation features bridge and skyscraper sketches [https://ideamache.ecologylab.net/v/1MnMBuSkTs/]. Undergraduate Christina Vaughn appropriates historic building photos to fill in the skyscraper sketch. The curation gives form to ideation involving the recycling of building designs and materials
    Interface Ecology Lab and Christina Vaughn
    Andruid Kerne
    Christina Vaughn?s World, an architectural design concept free-form web curation.
